🥂 Our paper "Gender and Willingness to Compete for High Stakes" has been published in JEBO. You can read the full paper (open access) here: https://authors.elsevier.com/sd/article/S0167268122004656

In short: using data from the Dutch version of the TV game show Deal or No Deal, we show that women have a particular dislike of competing against men, and that men are aware of this preference and exploit it when there are strategic incentives to do so.

A longer summary is on my website: https://www.dennievandolder.com/post/gender-competitiveness/

another great #retrogaming #book for @thevglibrary: fabien sanglard's Game Engine Black Book: Doom.

this one is a far more technical read than my usual narrative-heavy or historical book recommends. game engine black books generally tear apart the engine source code (if available) and provide an in-depth look at how the game works under the hood.

fabien's analyses are special, however. he not only painstakingly walks you through the architecture, memory manager, renderer, assets and npc AI, but also spends several chapters explaining the IBM PC and NeXT-based computers of the era. i've never known a technical writer with a better talented for understanding sheer complexity, and boiling it down into a series of graphs and illustrations.

https://fabiensanglard.net

title: View of How social media could teach us to be better citizens

last_post.content: What if building better social media platforms wasn't just good for escaping narcissistic billionaires? What if it could help us become better and more effective citizens? That's my argument in this paper: http://www.je-lks.org/ojs/index.php/Je-LKS_EN/article/view/1135818/1333

My dream:

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304407623000015?dgcid=raven_sd_aip_email

Visual cortex is affected by sounds. Does this mean it is multisensory? Does it represent sounds?

Today in Nature #Neuroscience (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41593-022-01227-x) Célian Bimbard and team find otherwise.

Sound-evoked activity in visual cortex was similar across neurons. Even neurons in hippocampus. It persisted after we cut fibers from auditory cortex!

This activity was predicted by… subtle body movements evoked by the sounds. It reflects brainwide state and behavior signals.

#NeuroNewPaper

Hey All,

I suck at stuff like this, and I know it, but I wanted to let everybody know that @TryCatchHCF died in his sleep on Tuesday due to cancer.

He was in his favorite place, surrounded by people he loved, and having talked with him quite a bit over the last few months, my sense is he was very much at peace with things.

As for me, I’ll miss our regular zoom calls, which started out with us talking about security stuff and hacking, and over time shifted to birds, ethics, and even a backpacking trip we were planning.

He was a pretty private guy, and as such I was a little reluctant to post anything about this, but I know a lot of people cared about him and I wanted to make sure I passed the word along.

I’m going to miss my friend Joe.

title: Moderation: Sharing the load, Sharing tickets, feedback and more. · Discussion #22979 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
Another server has your server blocked. You ask why. response?

"you should have blocked certain places by now but you haven't we don't trust you."

"we block as soon as we notice a problem, what are you suggesting?"

They refuse to tell us what we "should" have blocked or why.

There is no elegant way to find out a list of bad actors, no simple way to verify it.

I don't like just taking a block list on faith. That's what I want to address with this idea:

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/discussions/22979

#FediBlock 🧵

title: What’s the difference between a website and a Star Destroyer? Greebles.

last_post.content:
Having a library of UI components at your fingertips makes it easy to feel like you're ready to design - but if you don't have an underlying conceptual model, those components are as meaningful as the shiny lights on a Star Destroyer model.

Throwing some mock elements in a design can be a great way to spark conversations during discovery, but keep them out of demos (and certainly deliverables).

#UXDesign #UserResearch #UIDesign

title: GitHub - natemoo-re/tiny-decode: Decode HTML entities the browser-friendly way

last_post.content:
I just published 🤏 `tiny-decode`!

Traditionally, decoding HTML named character references requires a large table to store entity names and the code points to which they refer. Unless you take extreme care, this data can easily end up in your JavaScript bundle.

Using export conditions, `tiny-decode` only includes a few bytes in your browser bundles. Server bundles include the full table as usual.

`entities` 👉 19.64 kB gzip
`tiny-decode` 👉 0.56 kB gzip

https://github.com/natemoo-re/tiny-decode
